Rather, in so far as the Standing Orders require that senators be given 21 days notice of a possible third reading vote on the referendum Bills, that is what we are now giving them. In fact, we are giving them more than 21 days, as it turns out-21 days is a minimum requirement. It is a procedure which now puts all senators on notice. It is an alert sent out to them that they may be required to be in the chamber on 26 May, or on some later day if, for some reason, we do not get around to the third reading vote on that day, in order to exercise their right as senators elected by the people of their respective States or Territories to participate in the important question of putting a referendum proposal to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to re-emphasise that, whilst we have a certain assessing, deliberating, sifting role in relation to what questions might be put, the real purpose of this exercise at this time is to ensure that over the winter recess the Australian people have the time to consider the referendum questions. The hysterical display and dramatic theatrics that sometimes take place in these two chambers will not be available to us politicians during that winter recess. Thus they will not distract the people from their consideration of these matters out in the electorate over the three or four months leading up to a September referendum.

We are taking every step in scrupulous adherence to the Constitution and the Standing Orders which require such special majorities, right from the vote in the chamber through to the voting by the people in their various jurisdictions, on the questions that are put.

It is not my intention to traverse many of the matters which were raised incidentally and, strictly speaking, irrelevantly to this motion during the debate, except to say that I find it quite extraordinary that Senator Stone, for example, should be of the view that we should not-I recall him saying this quite clearly-entrench freedom of religion in the Constitution; that, rather, it should be left to the common law. Senator Stone seems to be unaware of the fact that under section 116 of the Constitution as it is presently drafted it is quite clear that in relation to the Commonwealth, but to the Commonwealth alone, there are certain restraints, and very properly so. Section 116 reads:
The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance, or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion . . .

That has been subject to constitutional interpretation in the High Court of Australia. Specifically, you will recall, Mr Deputy President, in the Jehovah's Witnesses case in relation to the defence power during the Second World War, and the Scientology case more recently, the matter has already been the subject of constitutional interpretation. What we are saying is that that very important constitutional provision, which at the moment only restrains the Commonwealth, should also be made to restrain the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

The common law which Senator Stone spoke about is, according to a decision of the Supreme Court of South Australia in the Grace Bible Church case only a few years ago, quite feeble and unable to withstand the assault of a State parliament on the religious freedom of those Australians living within its jurisdiction. It is yet another example of the blind attitude, the blanket attitude, of the Opposition as portrayed by Senator Stone, whereby the Opposition is opposed to all constitutional change leading to a situation where Australians can have less freedom than they presently enjoy.

The Opposition has already indicated that it is not a conservative party, not a conservationist force in the sense of trying to conserve the best values that underly our democratic institutions. Rather, the Opposition parties are preservationists. They want to preserve the Constitution as it was enacted in 1901. They take the same muddle-headed view as, I believe, some so-called conservationists take in relation to the question of forests and so on-that we have to preserve everything in order to conserve it, which is quite wrong as people would understand in that context.

The attitude that merely by preserving the words of our Constitution we can retain Australia as a vibrant, living, democratic, pluralist society is quite wrong. When we get the opportunity, which I hope the Australian people will be given in September, to strengthen our democratic institutions and to vote for rights against governments, to vote, in relation to religion, on trial by jury and the right to receive fair and just compensation if one's property is taken away by government, we should take it. They are rights we should be asserting against governments, because they are very important rights which inhere in us as ordinary human beings. They ought to be asserted quite forcefully in our fundamental constitutional arrangements against those governments that might try to infringe them.

Once again, without straying too much, it would seem to me to be very odd indeed for a political party in this chamber to vote against a proposition that the level of government which is closest to the Australian people and affects much of their everyday life-namely, local government organisations, councils and so on-should not have its position recognised in our constitutional arrangements. That seems to me to be quite an extraordinary proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't this just a Lionel Bowen retirement benefit?

—I am certainly not going to be distracted, Mr Deputy President. I am sure that you will call me to order shortly if I do not remain relevant at least to my own motion. If this motion is not passed, and if the Opposition keeps on rejecting a motion that there be a 21-day notice of a call preceding the third reading of a referendum Bill, then we will not be in a position to do our duty as senators, as a chamber of the Australian Parliament, and vote as we ought to, in fulfilment of our duties as legislators, elected by the Australian people, and vote on that third reading as to whether certain questions should be put to the Australian people or not. That surely would be a complete subversion of our role, our status, our duty as legislators. We have to vote on the third reading of these Bills if we are to fulfil our role in this chamber as elected representatives of the people. The 21-day notice merely alerts all senators to the fact that on around 26 May, or shortly thereafter, they ought to make themselves available for that vote, given the special majorities that are required. I commend the motion to the chamber.

That the motion (Senator Tate's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING (OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL) BILL (No. 2) 1987[COGNATE BILL:COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Messner had moved by way of amendment:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate expresses its view that all television audience reach restrictions be removed to allow a potential 100 per cent audience reach for all competitors on the condition that:
(a) the Government's moratorium on the introduction of pay and cable television be removed;
(b) the existing television licensing procedures be substantially streamlined;
(c) cross-media rules between pay and cable television and existing free-to-air broadcasters be introduced subject to `grandfathering' of existing holdings; and

(d) when the process of aggregation has been completed, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal conduct an inquiry into issuing new television licences in metropolitan markets, subject to a final decision being made by the Government''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The Opposition rejects the Government's proposed extension of television ownership limits which would have the effect of restricting the number of operators in the television industry to those who are presently there. There is no doubt that if the Opposition supported the Government's amendment it would entrench the domination of the existing networks and restrict the possibility of additional television stations coming into the system. The Opposition, consistent with its belief in deregulation, has a genuinely deregulatory policy which would enable real competition and real developments, and not simply favour those who are already in a very strong position and who would, if the Government's amendment succeeded, simply strengthen their respective holds on the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the Government has no answer to the fact that the Opposition's policy is truly deregulatory and would provide a framework for much freer entry into the television industry, by removing the moratorium on pay and cable television, streamlining licensing procedures, introducing cross-media rules between pay and cable television and existing services, and conducting an inquiry into the issue of new television licences once aggregation is complete. The fact that the Government has no answer is reflected in the debate which has already taken place in this chamber and which has focused far more on the vilification by Government senators of the Opposition, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and the shadow Minister, Senator Messner, than on defending the position it has taken. The Government has no substantial response to the Opposition's policy so it has resorted to attacks and abuse, and makes no attempt to indicate why it would not agree with what we have put forward.

It is clear also that members of the Government are not the only ones apparently confused about deregulation and what a free market really means. I was interested to hear yesterday morning an interview on AM with one of the owners concerned, Mr Christopher Skase, talking about the stand he took. In answer to a question, he said:
I'm a free marketeer and a great believer in full access to all markets because in the media in Australia today we've been faced with the massive cost pressures over a number of years . . .
That is largely the amount of money paid for the stations. I go on:

I believe at the end of the day, whether it's the ABC or commercial television or newspapers, we need to be able to aspire to put bigger markets together so that we can reasonably expect to undertake more Australian productions, and I have nothing to fear from any expansion of the market providing-
I should like that to be underlined; it is his word-
that those expansion platforms reasonably respect the rights and obligations of those people already in the market.

That is a very significant proviso for a free marketeer; provided those already in the system are protected with the empires they already have, they do not mind if there are a few changes. That is the free marketeer, Mr Christopher Skase, speaking on AM yesterday morning. The interviewer went on to say:
But the proposal to free up things like cable networks and pay TV-isn's that a more expansive policy than the Government's present one?
Mr Skase said:

No, I think that the Minister, Gareth Evans, has made it quite clear that they want to review pay and cable television and we certainly are supportive of that. Review is the operative word. It needs to be analysed in a public forum. The economic consequences in terms of employment in terms of opportunities for Australian production need to be evaluated. And as I say I think there is an opportunity for all parties to come together on a common ground for the finding of a solution in the best interests of the media industry in totality.

It is clear what Mr Skase intends. He wants to be protected and he will talk about inquiries and delays. There have already been sufficient inquiries into pay television for everybody to know what the arguments are. I suggest that any responsible Minister who is sufficiently informed about the industry would be in a position to make decisions right now, unless of course he has some interest in protecting anybody else and wants to delay for as long as possible. I would be interested to know what Mr Skase means when he talks about the best interests of the industry in totality. He certainly appears to me to be more interested in the position of those in the industry at the present time.

We are concerned about viewers. We recognise that television is the most popular form of entertainment in this country. We also recognise that a lot of people depend on televisions for their entertainment because for one reason or another they do not have the ability to go out as others do, perhaps because they are elderly or handicapped. A lot of people just do not have the ability to move freely about the community and to go to functions, and they rely on television. We want to work towards a system in which they will have the greatest possible opportunity for choice.

Let use look at what we are really talking about. In June 1987 the Parliament passed legislation relating to a 60 per cent viewing audience. Subsequent to that, Northern Star Holdings Ltd bought the Canberra CTC Seven station in August 1987. Mr Skase's purchases have been made since that time. Both of them were purchased knowing what the law was. It is clear that they have both been lobbying since then for the retrospective changes which would fix it up for them. One part of this new package related to the aggregation of areas, and I think there were four areas put together. The one I am interested in is area C, which takes in the Australian Capital Territory and the southern portion of New South Wales and out to the west, quite a large area with a fairly large viewing audience. Each of the three operators within that area, at Wollongong, Orange and Canberra, agreed to aggregation. The significance of that is that, having agreed and having notified this to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), they are now bound by that decision and aggregation will take place. The three stations will each be able to broadcast to the whole of the area, Channel 7 out to the other two and those two into Canberra. Under the legislation they are obliged to do so by the end of 1989, by the end of next year. I think Channel 7 indicated that it would hope to start at the beginning of 1989, and I think the other two stations each made commitments about when they would start, but certainly by December 1989, when they were required to do so.

There now seems to be some suggestion that aggregation will not happen or that there is some hitch to it, but the two stations-WIN 4 and the Orange-Wagga station-will still beam their programs into the Canberra-ACT area before the end of next year, possibly much sooner than that, and Canberra will then have three commercial stations in addition to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, which already exist here. There will be more competition; there will be more channels.

I referred earlier to the Government's suggestion of an inquiry into pay television, and I also said that enough was already known. There have already been significant inquiries. Pay television is a significant advance and development. It does not depend on advertising in the same way the commercial stations do; it relies on subscribers, and that is an additional development which ought to be made available to television viewers at the earliest opportunity. Under the Government's program I think it is very clear that it is not really interested in this and it wants to defer it as long as possible. I can only conclude that that is to protect those stations that are already operating.

Aggregation must go ahead. It will go ahead. The programs will come into Canberra, as I have indicated, from Wollongong and from Orange, and the diversity of television will be expanded within the terms of the laws passed by this Parliament in June last year to operate by or before the end of December 1989. I can see no reason why the Government would not accept the proposals which we have put forward. I certainly believe it ought to, because it is the viewers of television who will be the beneficiaries if that course is followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —An understanding of the issues involved in considering this legislation relating to ownership and control in the broadcasting industry requires understanding of the scale and type of changes which have occurred in broadcasting, particularly television, over a period of 30-odd years. The special problems for this industry, which was new some 30 years ago, were caused by factors typical of many Australian developments-vast distances and a relatively small, fragmented population. It was simply the lack of technology which prevented the development of any system other than the one which we have today. There were virtually no coaxial cable resources; microwave links were infrequent, unreliable and costly; broadcast equipment was massively expensive; copies or originals of programs had to be flown overnight between stations; boxes of newsfilm took days to get from overseas; and the cost of film processing was high. There was no alternative but for each city's broadcasters to look after themselves. Networking in anything but limited program buying, exchange and promotion was impossible. At the same time, potential local advertisers were captive; national advertising was extremely limited; Sydney and Melbourne controlled Australia. The smaller States, which sometimes could afford to pay only one-tenth or so towards the cost of an overseas program package, were very much junior members of these so-called networks.

SPEECH.PARA: It was against this background that third licences were granted in all States but Western Australia, a move which naturally caused much trepidation in the smaller States, which were steamrolled into the situation by their big brothers in the eastern States. Luckily, however, something else was happening which was to alleviate the lot of the smaller States in this regard, even if it was to create a whole new range of problems for the entire industry. Almost overnight it seemed there was a technological explosion. Satellites went up in droves; coaxial and microwave facilities mushroomed; videotape equipment became miniaturised and more efficient; electronic news gathering equipment came onto the scene; and television sets dropped in price. Suddenly it appeared that Australia was not such a big place after all.

One other significant event, a social one, occurred which was to have great bearing on the future. Harder economic times, accompanied by a changed social consciousness, led in part to the withdrawal of many large national advertising accounts from the smaller States, leaving the industry there much more dependent on smaller local accounts for revenue. It was at roughly this time that the advantages of fully organised networking became obvious and urgent. This sparked off a financial battle among the super rich media barons for control of the eastern State capitals and eventually the smaller States and regional networks. No doubt their motives ranged from pure greed to extending their influence and power, but whatever, the ensuing competition was generally beneficial to the viewing public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11.55 a.m., the debate is interrupted. Under Sessional Order I call on Questions without Notice.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, is in five parts and concerns Ethiopia. First, what is the current level of Australian overseas aid to Ethiopia, including famine relief and development assistance; and is it not true that the Government has cited this as a measure of its own concern for the suffering people of Ethiopia? Secondly, is it not now obvious that the ruling military regime is blocking international assistance getting to the people in need, especially in the Tigre province, and that the Ethiopian Government wishes to exacerbate the famine as yet another instrument, of its terror and oppression of the people? Thirdly, is it not significant that three million Ethiopians have now fled their country and are refugees in the Sudan and many other countries? Fourthly, given the Australian Government's professions concerning human, civil and democratic rights, why has the Government not directly condemned the Ethiopian Government as one of the most offensive and oppressive regimes anywhere in the world and why, in the same way as happened in Cambodia a decade ago, is the adoption of an appropriate foreign policy approach reserved until after the worst damage has already been done? Finally, has any Australian Minister or departmental official met Mr Dawit Giorgis during his current visit to Canberra and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some briefing on this matter which probably covers most of the terrain of Senator Teague's question, but he cannot expect a complete answer if he does not give me advance notice of his questions. I will do the best I can. The Government has monitored the situation in Ethiopia with mounting concern, and especially the developing famine caused by drought and the escalation of fighting in Eritrea and Tigre. I am not sure whether any government official or any other Minister has met with Mr Dawit Wolde Giorgis, who is currently visiting Australia, but we would certainly agree with his assessment, as a former chief relief official, that, while the current famine is not as bad as that of 1984-85, it certainly has the potential to be even more serious, especially as a result of the increased military activity in the northern provinces.

ANSWER.PARA: In early April the Ethiopian Government excluded all foreign aid workers from Eritrea and Tigre. Although a few United Nations workers have not been allowed back, the departure of the relief workers has grave implications for international feeding programs. Australia has expressed its concern about these developments to the Ethiopian Government. An officer from Nairobi is currently in Addis Ababa as is an Australian Development Assistance Bureau officer. We are also in contact with the United Nations and international relief agencies in Geneva and Rome. We shall also be speaking to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which is a close friend of Ethiopia. We are making adjustments to our current aid programs in Ethiopia to ensure that food relief supplies retain as much effectiveness as possible and to ensure that they reach the various regions affected by famine. The bulk of Australia's emergency assistance to Ethiopia in this financial year is channelled through international organisations and voluntary relief agencies.

I have a little more information about the aid. As part of the international effort to avert a repeat of the disastrous famine of 1984-85, in January this year we committed a further $3m in aid to Ethiopia, which brings the current total for 1987-88 up to $15.9m, including development assistance in the form of food aid, transport assistance and other non-food relief supplies. The food aid pledges by all donors now total 1.13 million tonnes against the estimated food aid needs for 1988 of 1.3 million tonnes. However, providing logistical support to enable the food aid to reach those most in need is still a major problem. We believe, overall, that the Australian response to the Ethiopian emergency has been timely, appropriate in composition and directed to areas of greatest need.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to ask his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to give a considered response to the various aspects of the question for the benefit of the whole Senate. In the absence of a statement that a Minister has not yet seen Mr Giorgis, a person who handled the whole of food relief from international agencies over the period from 1982 to 1986 and who was once a deputy foreign minister of the Ethiopian Government but who has now defected and who is as well informed as any person, I urge that steps be taken to meet him and to take fully into account the evidence that he can produce.

—I will ask Mr Hayden if he has any further information that he is able to give to the Senate in response to Senator Teague's questions and I will draw to his attention the latter part of Senator Teague's remarks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

QUESTION.PARA: W.A. Chamber of Commerce and Industry executive director Colin Barnett said there was no doubt unskilled positions were not being filled in Western Australia because people found it more attractive to remain on the dole.

ANSWER.PARA: In the context of making this assessment, it is also important to note that leading social workers within the country and leading trade unionists, such as Mr Bill Kelty, have seen the family allowance supplement as `better than a pay rise'. TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate by saying to Senator Bolkus that I thought he was very ungracious in not acknowledging that the problem supposedly identified by the West Australian yesterday was remedied in the 1982 Fraser Budget with the introduction of the family income supplement. ANSWER.PARA: I did not see today's reports. I would like to have a detailed briefing on what has in fact happened about this issue. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply. I just ask him: In light of the fact that the Senate will be adjourning for something over a couple of weeks, would he, in making those further inquiries-and the Opposition also wants to see a positive outcome-let me know before the Senate resumes, as soon as he has further advice, so that I can further consider the matter?
—Before the Senate adjourns?
—Before the Senate resumes.
—Well, although the Senate may be adjourning, the Cabinet will not. I will certainly indicate what I can to Senator Chaney if this matter comes before it soon.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. On 19 April this year, did the Government of Singapore arrest nine of its citizens, including a lawyer who defended some of the detainees after they were previously arrested? Do the detainees include people who worked for Catholic organisations? Were the people arrested for making a statement about the conditions in which detainees have been kept in the past? Does the Australian Government take any, and what, stance on this matter? Does the Government feel that it can do anything about the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm reports that the Government of Singapore has rearrested eight of the 22 persons who were detained in mid-1987 under the Internal Security Act, apparently for breaching the conditions imposed on their release from detention in December 1987. The eight, along with one other person who is presently abroad, published a statement in Singapore on 18 April alleging that their public confessions of involvement in a Marxist plot were false and the result of coercion and mistreatment while in detention. ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade understands that some of those detained did have connections with Catholic organisations. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONSUMER PROTECTION: INVESTMENT AND FINANCIAL ADVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I direct my question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs although, if you consider it more appropriate, it may have to be answered by the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the Minister aware that, according to investment adviser Austin Donnelly, in a recent edition of the Canberra Times, tens of thousands of investors have suffered serious losses because of inadequate, inaccurate or misleading information provided by some life insurance offices, investment companies, stockbroking firms and investment advisers? Does the Minister agree that the present system does not in fact adequately protect investors and that, therefore, there is a need to extend to investment and financial services the protection of consumer affairs legislation, which has already worked well in other fields? Does the Minister also agree that truth in labelling laws, which apply in other areas, should be extended to investment and financial services, and that the proposed new committee to advise the Attorney-General on companies and securities should include representatives of consumers as well as suppliers of investment schemes? Finally, will the Minister take prompt action to ensure that, when investing their life savings, investors have at least as much consumer protection as when they buy a $5 jar of coffee at a supermarket?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just seen the article that Senator Haines refers to and I have had an opportunity to peruse it briefly. It appears to me that the article is based on a couple of basic presumptions. Mr Donnelly said that the large losses in the share market crash were largely due to `inadequate, inaccurate and positively misleading information given to uninitiated investors'. I do not know whether we could very easily sit with that assessment of what happened last year in respect of the share market crash and whether in fact we can blame investment advisers, no matter how much their advice might have been misleading, for the enormity of the share market crash.

ANSWER.PARA: The other aspect of the article which I find very striking is that it does not seem to be backed up with any empirical evidence and, to that extent, it should be treated with some degree of caution. However, the Government has had under examination the points raised by Senator Haines which arise from the problem put forward by Mr Donnelly. Initially, it should be noted that under section 65a of the Securities Industry Act, protection is already afforded to investors against improper advice given by involvement advisers. The advice is seen to be improper if it does not have a reasonable basis for its being given. Also, in terms of whether advice is proper, an investment adviser must have regard to the investment objectives, the financial situation and the particular needs of the person involved. Under the same section, if a person in fact suffers losses because of such improper advice, financial damages are payable to that person.

As Senator Haines mentioned, the Government is in fact examining provisions in this area. We are re-examining this area as part of our proposal to establish an Australian Securities Commission. As part of those proposals, consideration is already being given to extending section 65a to cover oral advice as well as written recommendations, as is now the case.

Senator Haines also raised a couple of questions with respect to the committee advising the Government on the establishment of the Commission. I will pass on that request to the Attorney-General. I will also pass on to the Attorney-General for his consideration the point the honourable senator made about the possible need to extend the provisions of the proposed Australian Securities Commission legislation to cover other investment advisers, such as life insurance offices.

Indeed, I had the pleasure of meeting him again yesterday, having met him when I was in the Philippines earlier this year for the signing of the extradition treaty between our two governments. Mr Ordonez is a very distinguished lawyer who was most courageous during the years of the Marcos dictatorship and has now assumed his important post under the President of the Philippines, Mrs Aquino. The principal reason for his visit was to sign yesterday with the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia, Mr Lionel Bowen, a treaty for mutual assistance in criminal matters. Indeed, it is the first time that Australia has signed such a treaty for mutual assistance in criminal matters, and indeed for that matter, it is the first time that the Philippines has also entered into such an agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: This treaty enables us to each take evidence for the purpose of proceedings in relation to criminal matters instituted in another country, and more especially allows for the tracing of the location of property and assets of those who might be before the criminal courts of the other country and upon conviction in that other country allows for seizure and confiscation of those assets. As we know, this chamber has taken the view that in the fight against organised crime it is extremely important, if one successfully convicts a criminal, not simply to imprison that person or even to impose a fine, but also to confiscate the proceeds of crime, the ill-gotten gains, accumulated because of the criminal and other nefarious activity. If we can do that on behalf of governments in other jurisdictions, we will certainly help when those assets have been accumulated within Australia. It is obviously in the interests of the Philippines particularly to enter into such a treaty arrangement because there may well be assets held here which have been accumulated over the years by the Marcos cronies, as they are called. This particular treaty, which was signed only several months after the negotiations for the treaty took place earlier this year in Manila, is an important step in this cooperative regional approach to fighting crime in which the Government has engaged.

The fact is that criminals in their activities know and respect no borders, whether one is talking domestically within the Commonwealth of Australia or internationally, and it is extremely important that around this region we enter into these sorts of arrangements. Therefore, I am delighted that Secretary Ordonez was able to come to Australia so speedily to conclude this signing ceremony. I look forward to the ratification by the Philippines Senate of these very important treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. When is the Government expecting the final report of the Constitutional Commission-a report which has cost the Australian taxpayer nearly $6m and is now not even required by the Government for its decision on its constitutional reform proposals?

—There is a premise built into the latter part of that question which is not correct. The Government recently received the first report of the Constitutional Commission. It is not an interim report. It is a first report which represents the concluded views and recommendations on various issues and will be incorporated in part of the final report which is expected before the end of this financial year. In regard to the areas covered by the Government's referendum proposals, they are all dealt with in that first report of the Commission. The Government made its decisions on the referendum proposals in the light of the Commission's recommendations. The report will be released publicly by the Commission on 6 May after printing and will be tabled on 10 May 1988.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister telling the chamber that the final report of the Constitutional Commission is not necessary for the Government to look at its proposals and is a waste of money?

—I have already made it very clear that the Government's referendum proposals have been framed, taking into account the concluded views and recommendations on the relevant issues by the Constitutional Commission. I have also made it very plain, both at Estimates committee hearings and in answer to Senator Short, that the final report which will embrace more issues no doubt--
—A waste of money.

—No, it is not a waste of money. It is no more a waste of money than the very extensive work already undertaken by the Commission in its various committees, educational work and so on. The fact is that those other matters which may be canvassed in the final report of the Commission will enter into the general debate in the community about constitutional change. I imagine that it will provide very useful material for reflection on the next stage of constitutional reform that might be undertaken in this country. At the moment we are concentrating on those matters which were outlined by the Attorney-General yesterday.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to reports in yesterday's Press of comments made by Mr Ian Macphee, the member for Goldstein, on the subject of the Government's industrial relations and wages policies? Does the Minister agree with Mr Macphee that the Government's industrial relations and wages policies have been a great success? Has this been a major factor behind the massive increase in private sector employment that has been brought about in Australia since 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the report in the Australian Financial Review a couple of days ago quoting Mr Macphee as saying the types of things to which Senator Beahan has referred. I also saw reports of Senator Chaney taking Mr Macphee to task for daring to reveal in public his considered assessment of the situation.
—And businessmen taking Senator Chaney to task for taking Mr Macphee to task.

—I am about to quote some of the business people. The second part of the question was whether I agree with Mr Macphee that the Government's industrial relations and wages policies have been a great success. Of course I agree with him. That is not a biased assessment because I am a member of the Government. It is an irrefutable fact that there is no precedent in Australian economic history for the sort of wage restraint that has prevailed for five years in a period of almost continuously falling unemployment and, by Australian standards, a high rate of economic growth. There is no precedent in Australian history for that outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not just Mr Macphee and the Government who believe that. As Senator Button reminded me earlier, yesterday's Australian Financial Review referred to:
public conflict yesterday between the former Opposition frontbencher Mr Ian Macphee, and the Opposition's Senate Leader and industrial relations spokesman, Senator Chaney.

Several of the business representatives commented that they believed Mr Macphee's observations were reasonable-that the Government's industrial relations and wages policies had produced outcomes better than would have been achieved under the Opposition's policy-and that he-
should not have been rebuked for making them.

Mr Macphee was Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations from May 1982 until the then Government lost office in March 1983. Mr Macphee would be well aware of the sort of policy that he inherited-that was ever since the Fraser-Howard Government walked away from, and abdicated all responsibility for, a wages policy in May 1981. There was a wages explosion of 13 per cent, followed by a 14 per cent wages explosion in the next year. Mr Macphee came in at the tail end of the sort of outcome that that abdication of responsibility had induced. Mr Macphee is not to blame for what happened in 1981, or even in 1982 when he was the Minister, because by the time he became the Minister the course of events was firmly cemented in place and there was nothing much that Mr Macphee could have done about it.

Of course, it did burn into his brain what happens when there is a period of fairly strong economic growth and expectations of wage increases, without any Federal government wages policy. I find it remarkable that even a coalition Opposition as dim as the present one has apparently not learnt the lesson that Mr Macphee has learnt-that is, that the sort of wages policy, or rather non-wages policy, which the Opposition practised when in government and still advocates in any situation other than deep depression is likely to lead to a wages explosion. Mr Macphee has learnt the lesson. I wish that the rest of the Opposition could learn the same lesson. The final comment I want to make is that Senator Chaney's criticism of Mr Macphee, although he parades as the urbane Liberal and ostensibly defends--

TALK.START.PARA: —The urban Liberal.

—Well, an urbane urban Liberal, if you like, Senator Tate. Although he parades as an urbane urban Liberal, when somebody says something that he does not like, he shows himself for what he truly is. So much for free speech in the Liberal Party! Senator Chaney's response to Mr Macphee's well considered, well reasoned and well based comments about this Government's wages policy and industrial relations policy should be compared to the sort of policy which the Opposition practised in government and still advocates in opposition.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to Nukem and Euratom documents supplied to me by Jup Weber, a Greens member of the Luxembourg Parliament, which I passed to the Minister yesterday. The documents show that South African uranium was relabelled as uranium from Niger to get around Finnish and Soviet embargoes on Namibian and South African uranium. They also show that Euratom did not have to approve this deal because only the certificates of origin were swapped, not the safeguards obligations. I ask the Minister: Firstly, do these documents not show that origin swaps could take place in Europe between South African and Australian uranium without the intervention of Euratom or the knowledge of the Australian Government? Secondly, is it not a fact that uranium swapping procedures in the European Community (EC), which have become privatised and unregulated, are beyond the control of the Australian Government? Thirdly, is there not a contradiction between the Government's acceptance of such origin swaps in the EC, which could involve South African and Australian uranium, and its opposition to international flag swaps involving Australian and South African uranium? Finally, now that it has been proven that Australia's safeguards do not prevent circumvention of its ban on the exchange of South African and Australian uranium, what action does the Government propose to take to rectify the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I think, in answer to a six-point question from Senator Hamer, Senator Ray said that Senator Hamer was abusing Question Time by asking such a long question.
—It was a nine-part one.
—This is a five-part one.
—Is that the one you didn't get the right answer to?

—The point I make is that this is a long question and it would be more properly dealt with on notice. Asking such questions is, in my view, an abuse of Question Time. However, in the past I have complimented Senator Sanders on giving me notice of questions he intends to ask. It is true, as he said in his question, that last night he dropped a whole pile of documents on me and said, `Tomorrow there will be a question'. I make the point that there is a whole series of documents which are unofficial, leaked documents and which at this point have not been verified as being true and accurate documents. If Senator Sanders chooses to ask me a question on them with this degree of notice, he should not come into this chamber and pretend that he is operating on the basis of some principle, because what he is doing is political ambush. I do not mind political ambush; this is the place for it. Therefore, I shall deal with Senator Sanders as a political ambusher, not as a person who is acting on the basis of some great enshrined principle, because palpably he is not.
—Mr President--
—Order! I ask the Minister to reply to the question asked by Senator Sanders.

—On a point of order, Mr President: there has been a lot of abuse of Question Time which, strictly, is within Standing Orders. This has been a most disgraceful bloody afternoon. What the Minister has just said was out of order. I do not believe that he is entitled to attack a senator in that way and he should withdraw it.
—Order! I did not think that the Minister said anything unparliamentary. However, I ask Senator Cook to reply to the question.

—Mr President, I will reply to the question, as I believe my foregoing remarks were to the point of the question in any case. Senator Sanders has made allegations based on articles in Der Spiegel beginning, I think, on 15 January. He has made allegations based on questions in the European Parliament which were based on leaked papers, which we have investigated and replied to, and he has made allegations based on allegations made in the European Parliament by Madame von Blottnitz who, I understand, is in Australia but has not bothered to see me to discuss those allegations with me. He has made all of those allegations and now he has raised allegations made by a member of the Luxembourg Parliament. I guess we are moving from a German magazine to the European Parliament and to the Luxembourg Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: Underpinning all the questions which Senator Sanders has asked is a refusal to recognise the statement put down by the Government on 20 April dealing comprehensively with all of the allegations he made previously. What he has refused to recognise is the principle of equivalence in dealing with Australian origin nuclear material. He has refused to recognise that the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has said that there have been no diversions from the peaceful cycle to the weapons cycle during its 25 years of safeguarding the peaceful cycle. The IAEA itself has said that no Australian origin nuclear materials have been supplied for weapons use. The honourable senator has never recognised those things.

Let me turn now to the documents that the honourable senator has provided me with. As I say, they are from leaked correspondence between various people and organisations in Europe, including the German nuclear company Nukem, the Euratom Supply Agency, the Russian Ambassador in Luxembourg, and the counsellor to the Finnish Ambassador in Brussels. Additionally, the honourable senator has given me Press statements by members of the European Parliament which draw on all the corres- pondence he has given me as well to make allegations. What do they assert? They assert that Nukem has circumvented a Union of Soviet Socialist Republics embargo against South African uranium. From that, the honourable senator wants to draw me into a question about whether this somehow or other impinges on Australian safeguards in terms of Australian origin nuclear materials that are safeguarded in Euratom under the auspices of our safeguards regime, supervised by the IAEA and by Euratom.
The Press release that the honourable senator has attributed to Madame von Blottnitz, a member of the European Parliament, concludes with the following statement:
The Green MEP has presented this material to the Commission of Inquiry of the European Parliament which will continue further research into this whole business.
That is what Madame von Blottnitz has said. It continues:

In view of the fact that all of the allegations concern actions within Europe I endorse the idea that the matter be handled by the appropriate European authorities, if they care to do so on the evidence available. It is not a matter for Australia-there is no suggestion of the involvement of Australian material.

I could go on and answer the other questions, but I propose, as Senator Button did earlier in answer to a long question, to put those questions on notice and reply to the honourable senator more fully later.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First off, to allay some of Senator Durack's fears, the meeting that I had with the representatives from Shark Bay was not at the airport; it was in a city hotel. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian Government is conducting a process of consultation for the purpose of finding out what local people want. One would imagine that the Western Australian Government will determine its position after it has the results of those consultations. At this stage of the game the Western Australian Government is not asking me to list the whole of the area, or a part of it or none of it. —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the statements by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and other similar statements by the Government, and by Senator Cook today, that uranium for peaceful purposes was processed separately from uranium for military purposes. I also refer to the fact that the low and medium enrichment cascades at the Pierrelatte military plant in France were shut down in October 1982 and remain closed, and so the only source of medium enriched uranium for Pierrelatte is the Tricastin plant. I note the Minister's admission in this chamber that Australian uranium enters the Tricastin plant for enrichment and that this plant processes uranium for peaceful purposes. I ask the Minister: Will he not admit that the facts I have stated show that Tricastin has produced medium enriched uranium for both peaceful and military uses simultaneously? Does this not mean that contrary to Government statements, uranium for peaceful purposes and for military purposes is not processed separately? Will he admit that uranium physically mined in Australia is very likely to have entered the military cycle through the Tricastin-Pierrelatte link? Did he mislead the Parliament in saying that Tricastin only produced uranium for peaceful purposes? If the Minister denies the above facts, will he explain where Pierrelatte received its medium enriched uranium between 1982 and 1984 or, finally, give a categorical assurance that Tricastin was shut down and cleaned out between producing batches of medium enriched uranium for peaceful and military purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We again have a long question. I thank Senator Wood for observing the courtesy in giving me this question in advance. The only trouble with it is that Senator Vallentine gave me an identical question in advance. I was wondering which one would win the lottery of being called first by you, Mr President, to ask exactly the same question.
—At least they didn't ask it twice.
—Had Question Time been able to continue a lot longer, maybe they would both have asked the question.
—You could have had a duet.

—We could have had a duet. As with my earlier answer to Senator Sanders, let me go right back to all the other allegations that have been made before. Those allegations have been treated seriously, have been investigated by the Government and have been the subject of a report to this chamber. On 20 April the House of Representatives dealt with all those allegations and answered them. In the comprehensive way in which that answer was given, it dismissed those allegations, either wholly or, in the case of South African flag swaps and international flag swaps, dismissed them but identified a possible intent by some people. I do not know how many more times we have to go over this question. I find it just a trite exercise in headline-grabbing and an effort to try to regurgitate an old debate which has now been put to rest.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us go back to the elements of Senator Wood's question. He talked of `the Minister's admission in this chamber'. There has been no effort by this Government to be defensive or to conceal or cover up any aspect of what happens to Australian origin nuclear material when it goes abroad. I ask Senator Wood to please go back and read our statement again because, I remind him, it comprehensively covers all of those issues. So Senator Wood need not ask me a question about admission. We are not admitting anything. We are saying that this is the truth: this is what happens. There is no obligation of admission on our part. Senator Wood talked about the peaceful uses of uranium. I have said that he misunderstood the basic premise of what has been said. He has unilaterally refused to understand the principle of equivalence. Until Senator Wood understands that principle he will miss the tram and then want to misrepresent the whole debate.

In dealing with the allegations Senator Wood made before, I took an opportunity to bring him, Senator Sanders-who brought along his staffer-Senator Vallentine and, I think, Peter Milton and a few other people for a two-hour briefing with members of my Department and members of the Australian Safeguards Office so that there would be no difference between us on the facts. I thought after that meeting that there was no difference between us on the facts. However, Senator Wood has now asked a series of questions which shows that he does misunderstand or is seeking to misrepresent what in fact happens. Senator Wood continues to ignore the principle of equivalence which forms the basis of international trade in uranium for the production of energy for peaceful purposes. He does not yet recognise that uranium hexafluoride obligated to Australia is enriched at Tricastin to the level of 5 per cent. From Tricastin it moves to facilities which fabricate fuel rods for use in nuclear power stations. No Australian obligated material moves from Tricastin to the Pierrelatte enrichment plant. The fact that Senator Wood does not recognise that really just speaks volumes for how he does not understand the issue because to be enriched to the level of nuclear weapons it has to go to the level of 90 per cent. My advice is that the Tricastin plant is physically unable to enrich beyond 50 per cent. Therefore, it is a plant dedicated to enrichment to a level usable for peaceful purposes. I would have thought that that was quite clear.

Senator Wood asked whether I would admit that I misled the Parliament. Frankly, that is an offensive thing to say because, of course, that is not the case. To weave that into a question, I frankly find offensive and demeaning of the level of debate we have hitherto had and, in fact, an attempt to drag this through the gutter in terms of a political argument. It might be something from which a cheap headline can be gathered.

I am glad that it was not Senator Vallentine who asked the question because earlier in this debate she accused the Government of lying. I wrote Senator Vallentine a letter saying, `Senator Vallentine, are you correctly reported? If you are, where are we lying? What we have said is that we are investigating the allegations; we will report' and `I am advised that nothing has gone wrong'. We did investigate. There was no lie there. We did report. DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING (OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1988 and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 was interrupted for Question Time, I outlined the impact of changing technology on the development of the television industry in Australia. In particular I referred to initial developments in networking and the battle for control which developed among the media barons. Remote from all this activity, secure in the belief that ratings were for inferiors, was the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). It was not subject to the whims of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal or to communications legislation, nor did it have to justify itself commercially. The ABC could televise what it liked, wherever and whenever it liked. If, for example, people in Coober Pedy and the west of South Australia had to watch ABC Brisbane instead of programs produced in their own State, or Central Australians had to put up with rugby league instead of Aussie rules, that was too bad.

SPEECH.PARA: Two sets of rules had developed: one which said that nothing was wrong for a State controlled media body to have a 100 per cent reach and minimal regulation; and another set which said that this was wrong for privately controlled media. Today we have allowed to develop a policy which is not only obsolete and impractical but which also hinders the future development of a free, efficient and high quality broadcasting industry. It is time for a full facelift-not just a nose job. The industry and the public do not need or want bandaid protection. That may have been justified during the years of slow growth and change in the media but, in the blinding light from the technical and social explosions which have occurred recently and to foreshadow the changes that are yet to occur, a new approach is required, one which can offer the industry a stable platform upon which to plan its immediate future, free of doubt and any need for hesitancy. That is why the Government's proposed changes do not go far enough. There is scope for healthy debate as to how far these changes should go. The Opposition has logically engaged in that debate, although this Hawke Labor Government, because of its widely recognised arrogance, for which it has already paid dearly at the polls and for which it will suffer much more, regards any dissenting voice as puritanical heresy.

As far as the ABC is concerned, the Liberal and National parties retain a very strong commitment to public broadcasting. As the only existing truly national broadcaster the ABC has many special responsibilities which only it can hope to develop free of many of the natural restraints imposed on commercial broadcasting. However, the ABC's present structure, together with aspects of its management, is inhibiting it from developing its full potential. It requires strong management controls to ensure that the ABC is run on sound commercial principles and able to seek alternative financial support where possible. Corporate sponsorships of programs should be allowed and encouragement should be given to the farming out of program production to the private sector in a manner designed to encourage further development of the media production industry. ABC programs should reflect a balance of political attitudes and a diversity of community opinion. The ABC should be subject to the same standards regarding the broadcasting of blasphemous, indecent or obscene material as the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal applies to commercial broadcasters, thereby eliminating one area of current hypocrisy tolerated by this Labor Government. The ABC needs to improve efficiency in its broadcasting operations, particularly in radio where at present the ABC maintains three distinct operations. This will result in lower costs. In regard to commercial television we still have to adjust industry legislation to changed circumstances and provide a blueprint for the future. Ownership of individual networks means little. The ABC has always been under individual ownership, and throughout their history each commercial network has been dominated and controlled by the influence of a person or a family. Allowing ownership of a complete network would simply tidy up a presently messy situation and allow for more efficient operation of that network.

As for the term `reach', it would appear that some Government members confuse potential with fact. Having 100 per cent reach simply means the ability to offer a product or service to everybody. Whether the actual market share is 10 per cent or 100 per cent depends entirely on how much demand there is for the programs offered by any particular network. So what is wrong with 100 per cent reach? There are thousands of precedents in business, including the media and principally the ABC. Is not the only proven way of maintaining standards through competition? As long as ownership does not extend past one network and new entrants are allowed to compete, the industry would be provided with stability for future planning, the opportunity for efficient operation and healthy competition to maintain standards.

For the smaller States, huge increases in costs have already led to reductions in current affairs production and most forms of live television. This has been accompanied by a corresponding increase in national current affairs, documentary and soapie production in the eastern States, by the media networks and by independent producers. While this has not in all cases been undesirable, in one regard it has in that this de facto form of network control leaves little opportunity for the development of local media in those smaller States. Networking in this fuller sense would provide the opportunity for controlling diversity of production among the States. Increased competition, monitored and encouraged through the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, would ensure that. Advertising revenue and corporate sponsorship is finite and, in any battle, the smaller States can only win a decreasing slice of the cake.

Any comparison with Canada, where the only known study of reach effects has been done, is ludicrous. Not only are the market regions totally different from those in Australian but also some of the key Canadian market areas come under at least fringe influence from the United States of America. Australian communities can best be served by a policy of minimal restriction and healthy competition engendered by appropriate new licences granted on the basis of local need and demand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I thank Senator Messner. This scenario fits perfectly with the introduction--
—You have your own audience.

—Senator Cook ought to be aware that this scenario fits perfectly with the immediate introduction of pay television, and with the future expansion on the Telecom Australia optical fibre network which will be progressively completed after 1995. Just a month ago, the head of the Broadcasting Tribunal, Ms Deidre O'Connor, told an investigating committee in the other place that she could `see no problem with the licensing of networks' as long as the Tribunal had the power to look at the conduct of the networks. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's problem, she said, was dominance by the three Sydney based networks over local stations-a judgment which sits perfectly with the concern of the coalition about the Government's 75 per cent proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The underlying factor is, of course, cost. Reception and quality of reception, more sophisticated and improved forms of transmission, and viable unit costs of receivers have all been good for the public but they carry expensive price tags and the inescapable fact of life in the mass media business today is that only the big blokes can afford to pay the big bills, and if they cannot get the returns for their investments they take Australian media money where it can get results-overseas. A move to just 75 per cent reach may, in the short term, win a few media friends for the Government but it will provide a mere bandaid for the industry and the viewing public.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't bring any more competition, does it?
—In fact, it will reduce competition. It might win the Government one new friend in the media but that is all; it will not do anything for the Australian public.
—Mr Howard wants 75 per cent.

—Mr Howard wants 100 per cent with new entrants and greater competition. Can honourable senators imagine this Government saying no to Bond Media if a little further down the track another purchase raises the target to 76, 77 or 80 per cent? The only terms under which 75 per cent could possibly be acceptable for a viable industry in the future is if it is accompanied by the removal of barriers to competition.

SPEECH.PARA: How was this magical figure of 75 per cent reached in the first place if it was not a convenient number to fit a purchase which has already been made, in defiance of existing legislation? So from now on one media baron is to have an advantage over the rest. The others cannot extend their operations into true networks because to do so they would have to exceed this magical new figure pulled out of thin air to please one person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did that?
—This Government.
—No, it was Mr Keating, I think.

—Well, he is part of this Government, and so is the Minister particularly responsible for communications. Senator Evans. Christopher Skase has said that the position adopted by the coalition on the issue of ownership is at odds with our commitment to a more market oriented approach to economic and business policy. This demonstrates that Mr Skase, a newcomer to the industry, has considerable lack of understanding of the elements required for a freer market in the context of the industry in which he now finds himself prominent. It is not sufficient to allow broadcasters simply greater access to population if the industry is to develop. This must be accompanied by freedom of access to individuals and companies and by new forms of broadcasting and communication such as pay television and so on. Unless we have both conditions we do not have a freer market. The Government's policy would have the effect of entrenching an oligopoly consisting of three major players-Skase, Bond and Lowy-with one of them having an unfair advantage over the others and with the doors closed to any further competition. This is the very antithesis of a freer market, which requires increased competition.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested that because the coalition wishes to go further than the Government in allowing audience reach we should accept the Government's 75 per cent proposals for the time being and open up the market to new entrants when we come to office, which will undoubtedly occur at the next election. But to go only part way now would close the door on greater competition in the future because by the time any future action could be taken this oligopoly would be firmly entrenched and too well established for new entrants to break into the industry. Logically then, unless increased reach were linked to allowing new entrants, less competition would result and overall service to the public would deteriorate. Until such time as both requirements are met one can see no logical rationale for lifting the permissible reach limit above 60 per cent-unless one is among the millions of Australians who have come to realise that this Government can be bought. Rules can be changed for one if one is big enough.

And what will happen with Australia's 139 radio stations? Luckily for the general public, there are four times as many of them as there are television stations. Unluckily for the industry and the people who work in it, not all of them will survive, certainly not under their current identities. Already satellite connections and electronic placement of local spot advertisements are replacing locally produced programs. Networking in radio is even more inevitable than in the television industry, and the sooner this Government faces the fact that it simply will not be able to stop it from happening the better. Then at least the broadcasting industry as a whole can be given some complete guidelines for the future and, equally as important, can be effectively monitored. To quote that self-proclaimed media luminary, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans):

. . . it is becoming increasingly difficult to live with, in Australia, the no less than seven major Acts, together with a mass of associated regulations and by-laws, that govern electronic communications.

It is difficult to see how bending outdated and inadequate rules at whim can be a worthwhile exercise while a simpler, less regulated and more suitable alternative is so obvious. I quote the Minister again, from his media statement of 19 April:
The practical effect of this tangle of legislation is to deter the faint-hearted, confuse newcomers and protect incumbents.

Apparently Mr Skase is about to be elevated from the standing of confused newcomer to protected incumbent. There can be no doubt that this Government intends Mr Skase to be a protected incumbent. The comments by Mr Skase on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation current affairs program AM yesterday morning revealed this and confirmed that Mr Skase completely misunderstands what constitutes a free market. I quote from the AM transcript:

Skase-I'm a free marketeer and a great believer in full access to all markets because in the media in Australia today we've been faced with massive cost pressures over a number of years and I believe at the end of the day whether it's the ABC or commercial television or newspapers we need to be able to aspire to put bigger markets together so that we can reasonably expect to undertake more Australian productions and I have nothing to fear from any expansion of the market providing that those expansion platforms reasonably respect the rights and obligations of those people already in the market.
Interviewer-But the proposal to free up things like cable networks and pay TV-Isn't that a more expansive policy than the government's present one?

Skase-No, I think that the Minister Gareth Evans, has made it quite clear that they want to review pay and cable television and we certainly are supportive of that. Review is the operative word. It needs to be analysed in a public forum the economic consequences in terms of employment in terms of opportunities for Australian production need to be evaluated. And, as I say, I think there is an opportunity for all parties to come together on a common ground for the finding of a solution in the best interests of the media industry in totality.

Quite clearly Mr Skase expects special privileges for those already in the market against any potential new entrants. He wants the entrance of new players delayed. He wants deals done `in the best interests of the media industry'. Note that he says `media industry', not `the Australian people'. All this is the very antithesis of a free market. It is arrant nonsense for Mr Skase to claim to be a free marketeer. A freer market in the television industry requires that anyone who wants to have a go at providing a television service to the Australian community, whether broadcast television, cable television or some other form of pay television, should have the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable senator. It is for those potential new service providers to judge the economics and likely profitability of their proposals, not the existing players or the Government in some cosy deal, as Mr Skase appears to want. Replacing the tangle, as the Minister has called it, would be worthwhile if, in addition to simplifying the situation, the policy pursued by the replacement legislation catered to the long term requirements of the industry and the public. It does not. It does not go far enough. If honourable senators do not believe that, they should go and ask the people in Coober Pedy, or for that matter here in Canberra, whether they are happy with the standard of television service they get, and ask the broadcasting industries in the smaller States whether they are happy with the direction in which they are being pushed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting to hear Government speakers quoting Press pundits on this issue, as if the print media were expert on the electronic media. It may have been able to lay some claim to this type of credibility once, in the days when the print barons ran all media, but there is very little reason for the print moguls to come out in support of the new breed of electronic magnates-quite the reverse. Would one sign a hire purchase agreement without ensuring that one got a warranty as well? That is why the Opposition is taking the stand it is taking on this legislation. Without some guarantees for the future of the broadcast industry, this legislation boils down to an old Act of convenience. Following the old mates Act, we have the new mates Act. This legislation is before us because it suits both factions of the Labor party.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are actually three factions in the Labor Party.

—There are two main ones. Concentration of power in a few big business and government hands, as this legislation provides, is the modus operandi of the Labor Right, whose members are committed to the corporate state, consisting of big government, big business and big unions. Members of the Left, no doubt, acquiesce, believing that, if in the future they are able to reclaim their party and pursue their socialist objective, it will be easier to achieve that against a few big businessmen than against a business sector with a broader spread of ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is anathema to Liberals because it entrenches concentration of power in the media industry. Such concentration of power is anathema to liberalism, morally wrong and detrimental to our economy. A Liberal approach requires diversity of ownership and the freedom for anyone who wants to take the risk of establishing a new enterprise and having a go to be able to do so. The Government, with its corporate state mentality, has rejected coalition initiatives with regard to this legislation to achieve diversity by removing barriers to entry to the industry. Those initiatives that we have taken include the following amendment which has been moved by our side:

At end of motion add ``, but the Senate expresses its view that all television audience reach restrictions be removed to allow a potential 100 per cent audience reach for all competitors on the condition that:
(a) the Government's moratorium on the introduction of pay and cable television be removed;
(b) the existing television licensing procedures be substantially streamlined;
(c) cross-media rules between pay and cable television and existing free-to-air broadcasters be introduced subject to `grandfathering' of existing holdings; and

(d) when the process of aggregation has been completed, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal conduct an inquiry into issuing new television licences in metropolitan markets, subject to a final decision being made by the Government''.

I urge the Government, even at this late stage, to accept this amendment, to the advantage of all Australians, because, unless removal of barriers to entry to this important industry is linked to a relaxation of limits on audience reach, an unacceptable concentration of power will occur. The only other way to prevent greater concentration of power is to maintain the status quo. I urge honourable senators to support the Opposition amendment but, should that fail, this legislation must be opposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, Senator Chapman, has just referred to the amendment to the motion for the second reading that has been moved by the Opposition. the Minister or some licensing authority would always retain ultimate control over such technologies as they would need to be licensed under some broadcasting or radiocommunications legislation. —Good. I would just like to go to the point about censorship standards being endorsed by the Federal Government. Of course, censorship standards endorsed by the Federal Government may vary. Senator Evans, for the first time in the history of Australia, legalised the sale, hire and distribution of hard-core pornography. That is not my term; it is the term used by the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans, in the explanatory memorandum to the Classification of Publications Ordinance which was brought into this chamber in 1984. I make the accusation openly and bluntly that this was an attempt to hoodwink the public. Indeed, the document which was presented to that meeting of Attorneys-General referred to the source of this material.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the chamber that we are talking about X-rated material which the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans, wanted to rename ER and which a minority of members of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material recommended should be classified NVE-non-violent erotica. Going to the source of this material, the Ministers received a document from the Attorney-General's Department which was prepared by the Film Censorship Board. The Board said:
Ninety per cent of the hard-core material in Australia and Canada originates from the USA.
The Board continued:

It should also be noted that information provided by the Canadian police from the Ontario based pornography squad strongly suggests that 90 per cent of the Canadian hard-core market is supplied from the USA. Reference to the control by organised crime of the material that is currently annexed was deleted from the document. Here are the two documents. The fact is, as is known fairly broadly, and as I was able to ascertain when I was in the United States last year-and this can be seen from my observations on page 315 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material-that all this can be proven and shown. Organised crime is heavily involved in the production of video pornography in the United States. The centre for the production of about 85 per cent of this material is Southern California. As has been indicated in evidence to the Committee, the United States is the main source of the supply of video pornography including that which receives the X classification from the Film Censorship Board. TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

SPEECH.PARA: The evolution of the Opposition's response through successive stages has been wondrous to behold. It reminds me a little of the old lawyer's story about defending the man who was charged with breaking a window. The first line of defence was, `room `ad no window'; the second line, `the window wasn't broken'; the third line, `if it was broken, I didn't do it'; and the fourth line, `if I did do it, well it was an accident'. What we have here is what I would describe as a fascinating new phenomenon which is really going to intrigue mathematicians. Until now it has been universally accepted that 75 is on the way from 60 to 100-it is 15 steps down the track, with another 25 to go. But the Opposition has now come up with a proposition that 75 is not on the way from 60 to 100.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is new maths.
